column4: i deleted my home folder ~/ part-accidentally (ubuntu is to blame too). where do i get a copy of the default home folder files ?   /etc/skel has only couple .bash config files
i had a sub directory named '~' in my home directory: ~/stuff/~ . i was in stuff and did rm -rf ~/ hoping to remove stuff/~/ , but iot removed home directory instead.
well. i blame linux too.. the intuitive / expected command does something totally unexpected
what ? the linux command for deleting a sub directory is rm -r dirname/
atleast that's how it works for most of the directories..
that's exactly what i typed
rm -r ~/
Do not type that command in here again or I will ban you.
well i didn't create it. i was installing some software, and it created it automatically
hadoop

it's not a question of figuring out some extra escape variable syntax.. if linux has to gain popularity, it should let users shoot themselves in the foot so easily.. i mean is it that hard to add some extra precautions.. if the person who wrote rm could add an -i option, they might as well add a 'don't delete home directory ~, if there is a sub directory ~' option
*should not
of course it is the user error, why are u stating the obvious? all i'm saying is that linux shouldn't let them make the errors so easily
like i said before, adding the -i only makes u blind to it after a while..
dude... i know how to do it now
my only rant is why the default behaviour of rm is to 'oh let me remove the parent directory ~ instead of the sub directory ~'
